Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: Having just moved in, they prepare a small cake to share with nearby neighbors when they happen to meet.
Situation2: They participate in a national continuing education program to maintain licensure and expertise in the latest treatments.
Story:
I had just moved into the new apartment complex last week, and today, I finally had a free afternoon. I baked a small lemon cake, hoping to introduce myself to the neighbors and maybe make a good impression. As I wrapped the cake, I glanced at my phone and saw a reminder: the national continuing education webinar for pharmacists was starting in fifteen minutes. It was a crucial session, covering new guidelines I needed to stay licensed and competent at work. 

I looked at the cake, then at the clock. I knew the neighbors would likely be home now, and I wanted to be friendly, to show I cared about being part of the community. But I also knew how important it was to keep up with my professional responsibilities. If I missed the session, I’d fall behind, maybe even risk my standing at the pharmacy. My heart pounded as I stood in the hallway, cake in hand, torn between the warmth of a neighborly gesture and the pressing duty of my profession.
